Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2015, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow to take transformative approaches to grand challenges in biology that employ biological collections in highly innovative ways. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Benjamin Freeman is "Understanding tropical montane biodiversity: Is interspecific competition important?" The host institution for this fellowship is the University of British Columbia, and the sponsoring scientist is Dolph Schluter.

Tropical mountains are the most biodiverse terrestrial ecosystems on Earth. This "megadiversity" arises largely because species occupy narrow elevational distributions. Elevational specialization is due to both abiotic and biotic factors, but the influence of interactions between species has been largely ignored. Interspecific competition is an important biotic interaction that can influence how species' traits evolve and where species live on both regional and local spatial scales. Typically, interspecific competition is mediated by functional traits; therefore, species that have similar traits, e.g., similar beak size and shape, compete for resources more intensely than species with very different functional traits. The fellowship research uses museum collections including the American Museum of Natural History to generate a large, freely available database of functional traits in songbirds. Using this database, hypotheses about interspecific competition mediated by functional traits can be examined as an important mechanism that explains why tropical mountains harbor such diverse avifaunas. Specifically, the hypotheses are 1) Functional traits explain what species of tropical birds can occur at the same elevations along elevational gradients, 2) Interspecific competition shapes the geographic distributions of tropical montane birds, and 3) Interspecific competition drives phenotypic evolution in tropical montane birds. Results promise to explain why tropical montane regions are biodiversity hotspots and test the validity of current "abiotic-only" models.

Training goals are to gain expertise in data analysis and acquire quantitative skills relevant to biodiversity science, such as species distribution modeling and macroecological analyses. Educational outreach involves mentoring and providing research experiences for undergraduate biology students. Public outreach includes lectures and continuing to publish articles in the Living Bird, a quarterly magazine with a circulation of more than 60,000.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biodiversity runs riot in the tropics. There are far more species living in tropical latitudes than there are in temperate regions. For example, more bird species breed along a 30 km transect stretching from the high Andes to the Amazon in Peru than breed in the entirety of North America. Tropical mountains harbor such exceptional biodiversity in part because different species are packed into different elevational zones. In the Peruvian Andes, most bird species only live within a narrow elevational zone of around 1,000 m—this despite that the mountains are over 4,000 m tall, and that birds have wings and could easily fly to lower or higher elevations. My research seeks to explain why tropical mountains are the hottest of biodiversity hotspots. I have addressed three main questions during my tenure as a NSF collections-based research postdoctoral fellowship in biology.

 

Why are there so many kinds of birds on tropical mountains in the first place?  

A central goal of evolutionary biology is to understand the origin of Darwin’s “endless forms so beautiful”—the evolution of reproductive barriers between populations. Birds use song to choose their mates, and thus song divergence drives reproductive isolation. But why do some birds rapidly evolve different songs while others do not? I use collections of audio recordings of birdsong to conduct field experiments that “ask the birds themselves” if they recognize song from a related population that lives elsewhere (minimal reproductive isolation based on song) or ignore it (substantial reproductive isolation based on song). I have calculated song discrimination for 125 such sister pairs; this novel dataset will be generally useful to the scientific community interested in signal evolution and speciation. Thus far I have found that 1) the ability of some species to learn their song does not promote divergence as is commonly thought but is instead associated with slower evolution of reproductive isolation (Freeman et al. 2017 Evolution), 2) whether related populations live in similar or different habitats does not matter for song evolution, contradicting the idea that acoustic adaptation to different environments is important to speciation (Freeman et al. in prep), and 3) although we know there are far more species of birds in the tropics compared to the temperate zone, current taxonomy greatly underestimates species richness of tropical taxa: for example, I document 21 cases where related populations of the same species ignore each others’ song and should be considered distinct species (Freeman et al. 2017 The Auk).

 

Why do birds live in such narrow elevational zones?

Since Darwin, evolutionary ecologists have suggested that competition is fierce in the tropics. I investigated the hypothesis that competition is an important reason why tropical birds live in such narrow elevational zones. I evaluated cases where two closely related species “replace” one another at different elevations, but where there is also a region where only one of the species is present. If competition prevents elevational replacements from expanding their ranges, then species should expand their distribution when released from this pressure. I compiled large databases of locality information from museum and citizen science collections to test this prediction for 55 case examples. I found evidence that competition matters in around half of these case examples—in 25 cases, species expanded their environmental distribution in the absence of their putative competitor (Freeman et al. in prep). This comparative analysis is an example of using collections to conduct rigorous tests of longstanding ecological hypotheses, and shows that competition is indeed important—birds are often able to live in a broad range of elevations, but are prevented from doing so by competition with related species.

 

Is global warming changing where birds live along mountain slopes?

 

Global warming can be considered a massive unplanned experiment testing the hypothesis that temperature explains where species live. Most species are shifting their distributions to historically cooler places, but though tropical taxa are often predicted to be disproportionately sensitive to temperature changes, there is very little data from the tropics. I addressed this data gap by documenting where bird species live along a Peruvian mountain slope and comparing my data to historical records from the same location. My field data support predictions that tropical birds (and tropical taxa more generally) are more responsive to warming than are temperate zone species (Freeman et al. in prep). Moreover, as a result of this disproportionate sensitivity, warming is leading to stronger upslope shifts that lead to local extinctions at mountaintops in the tropics (but not the temperate zone; Freeman et al. in prep). Thus, although the rates of warming are highest at high latitudes, it is the places on Earth with the greatest biodiversity—tropical rainforests— where warming is most likely to lead to local extinctions. This result provides strong evidence supporting the call to make conserving entire elevational gradients a primary goal in tropical biodiversity conservation.
